item.title: Climate Negotiators Reach an Overtime Deal to Keep Paris Pact Alive
item.media:description: Michal Kurtyka, president of the climate talks in Katowice, Poland, leapt over his desk as the final session ended.
item.media:credit: Janek Skarzynski/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The deal puts in place detailed implementation rules, but analysts said it was now up to individual countries to honor their commitments.
item.dc:creator: BRAD PLUMER
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: How McKinsey Has Helped Raise the Stature of Authoritarian Governments
item.media:description: Monuments to Kiev’s founders burned during anti-government demonstrations in 2014. The protests led to the ouster of President Viktor F. Yanukovych, who rose to power with the help of McKinsey.
item.media:credit: Efrem Lukatsky/Associated Press
item.description: At a time when democracies and their basic values are increasingly under attack, the iconic American company has sometimes served clients in ways that directly counter American interests.
item.dc:creator: WALT BOGDANICH and MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Ruling Striking Down Obamacare Moves Health Debate to Center Stage
item.media:description: Representative Nancy Pelosi, the top House Democrat, and others in her party vowed to move swiftly to defend the health care law.
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger/The New York Times
item.description: A Texas judge’s ruling that the Affordable Care Act is unconstitutional may not stand, but it will elevate health care as a pressing topic in a divided Washington.
item.dc:creator: SHERYL GAY STOLBERG, ROBERT PEAR and ABBY GOODNOUGH
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: What the Obamacare Court Ruling Means for Open Enrollment
item.media:description: Open enrollment ended in most places on Saturday, but some states’ enrollment periods extend into January 2019.
item.media:credit: Joe Buglewicz for The New York Times
item.description: A federal judge in Texas struck down the Affordable Care Act a day before the deadline to sign up for next year’s coverage in most states.
item.dc:creator: SARAH MERVOSH
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: In Weaponized Courts, Judge Who Halted Affordable Care Act Is a Conservative Favorite
item.media:description: On Friday, Judge Reed O’Connor ruled that the Affordable Care Act’s individual mandate requiring people to have health insurance “can no longer be sustained as an exercise of Congress’s tax power.”
item.media:credit: Pablo Martinez Monsivais/Associated Press
item.description: Judge Reed O’Connor, a federal judge in Texas, has often sided with Republicans in their challenges to Democratic policies.
item.dc:creator: MANNY FERNANDEZ
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: Ryan Zinke, Face of Trump Environmental Rollbacks, Is Leaving Interior Department
item.media:description: Mr. Zinke had been the subject of at least a half-dozen federal investigations, one of which was recently referred to the Justice Department.
item.media:credit: Cliff Owen/Associated Press
item.description: Mr. Zinke is the latest Trump administration official to exit his position facing questions of ethical conflict.
item.dc:creator: JULIE TURKEWITZ and CORAL DAVENPORT

item.title: Zinke’s Likely Successor Is a Former Oil Lobbyist Who Has Influenced Trump’s Energy Policy
item.media:description: David Bernhardt, deputy secretary of the Interior, is expected to step in as acting head of the department in the wake of Mr. Zinke’s departure.
item.media:credit: David Zalubowski/Associated Press
item.description: With the Interior secretary's departure, the agency will likely be run for a time by David Bernhardt, a man who has played a central role in opening up public lands to drilling and mining.
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT

item.title: Mulvaney Called Trump a ‘Terrible Human Being’ in 2016
item.media:description: A spokeswoman for Mick Mulvaney said remarks disparaging President Trump were “old news” and had been made before he had met Mr. Trump.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner/The New York Times
item.description: Mick Mulvaney, President Trump’s pick to be acting White House chief of staff, made the comment in a debate, and offered similar remarks in a post on his campaign Facebook page.
item.dc:creator: MAGGIE HABERMAN

item.title: As the Trumps Dodged Taxes, Their Tenants Paid a Price
item.media:description: Jack Leitner outside the Beach Haven Apartments in Brooklyn. A tax scheme created by the Trumps, who owned the building, artificially inflated rent paid by him and thousands of other tenants.
item.media:credit: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
item.description: A phony business the Trumps created to siphon wealth from their empire drove up the rent for thousands living in their buildings.
item.dc:creator: RUSS BUETTNER and SUSANNE CRAIG

item.title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
item.media:credit: Katy Grannan for The New York Times
item.description: Ellen DeGeneres is not as nice as you think. Your apps aren’t keeping your location secret. Our most popular recipes of 2018. And more.
item.dc:creator: KALY SOTO

item.title: Michael Cohen, Mick Mulvaney, Brexit: Your Weekend Briefing
item.media:credit: Stephanie Keith for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
item.dc:creator: INYOUNG KANG and SARAH ECKINGER

item.title: Don’t Tear Up This Treaty
item.media:credit: Ryan Garcia
item.description: Arms control isn’t perfect. But abandoning treaties without a plan for the future is dangerous.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: How to Be More Resilient
item.media:credit: Ariel Davis
item.description: Some people are just genetically tougher. But you can train your brain to better handle stress.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD A. FRIEDMAN

item.title: Where Are All the Female Architects?
item.media:credit: Simone Noronha
item.description: Nearly half of architecture students are women. Why are so few sticking with the industry after graduation?
item.dc:creator: ALLISON ARIEFF

item.title: So, I Asked People in Saudi Arabia About Their Mad, Murderous Crown Prince
item.description: The U.S. has leverage over Riyadh. Let’s use it.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KRISTOF

item.title: Michael Cohen Got Wise. Will America?
item.media:credit: Ben Wiseman
item.description: His sad journey is an extreme version of the country’s.
item.dc:creator: FRANK BRUNI

item.title: Who Killed The Weekly Standard?
item.media:description: Steve Hayes, editor in chief of The Weekly Standard, at his office in Washington.
item.media:credit: Lexey Swall for The New York Times
item.description: The bureaucratic mind has a temporary triumph.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BROOKS

item.title: Is There Such a Thing as an Authoritarian Voter?
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.description: Political scientists want to know. They’re not the only ones.
item.dc:creator: MOLLY WORTHEN

item.title: Survival of the Sneakiest
item.media:description: A bull elk on the Nature Conservancy’s Zumwalt Prairie Preserve. Aggressive bulls win control of harems, but unassuming males sometimes sneak in and pass along their own genes instead.
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.description: Stealth can win out over speed and strength in the arms race of evolution.
item.dc:creator: DAVID P. BARASH

item.title: Internet Church Isn’t Really Church
item.media:description: A service at the Christian Cultural Center in Brooklyn. More churches are offering live-streaming of their services, but does that offer the benefits of being in a room with fellow worshipers?
item.media:credit: Demetrius Freeman for The New York Times
item.description: Showing up in person is exhausting, especially compared with live-streaming. But being together is the whole point.
item.dc:creator: LAURA TURNER

item.title: The Family History DNA Can’t Reveal
item.media:credit: Benjamin Currie
item.description: I could try to find out where my ancestors may have come from, but that is never going to show me what I’ve actually inherited.
item.dc:creator: KAITLYN GREENIDGE

item.title: A Museum Honoring Judy Chicago, Star of Feminist Art? Not in This ‘Sleepy Little Town’
item.media:description: Judy Chicago may be a star of the art world, but a proposed museum in her honor has roused a fierce dispute that is dividing Belen, N.M.
item.media:credit: Adria Malcolm for The New York Times
item.description: New Mexico has long been a mecca for artists. But a proposal in the feminist artist’s hometown, Belen, to open a museum in her honor has exposed cultural fractures.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Pete Davidson Is Largely Absent From ‘Saturday Night Live’
item.description: Davidson made only brief appearances in the final live show of 2018, hours after publishing an Instagram post that elicited concern about his safety and well-being.
item.dc:creator: DAVE ITZKOFF

item.title: Father of Migrant Girl Who Died in U.S. Custody Disputes Border Patrol Account
item.media:description: Ruben Garcia, the director of an El Paso shelter that is caring for the father of Jakelin Caal Maquin, who died in United States custody this month. Mr. Garcia delivered a statement from the lawyers of Jakelin’s father at a news conference on Saturday.
item.media:credit: Rudy Gutierrez/The El Paso Times, via Associated Press
item.description: The father of Jakelin Caal Maquin said his daughter was healthy before they were detained by the authorities in the New Mexico desert this month.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Investors Have Nowhere to Hide as Stocks, Bonds and Commodities All Tumble
item.media:description: On the New York Stock Exchange, as at other exchanges around the world, shares have been pummeled.
item.media:credit: Mark Lennihan/Associated Press
item.description: For the first time in decades, every major investment has fared poorly. The question is whether trouble in the markets will undermine economic growth.
item.dc:creator: MATT PHILLIPS

item.title: Amid Russia Tensions, Ukraine Moves Toward Separate Church
item.description: Ukraine took a major step toward establishing an Orthodox Church independent of Moscow, a move likely to increase already heightened tensions
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Lawyer’s Status Throws Genocide Conviction of Khmer Rouge Leader Into Doubt
item.media:description: Journalists in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, in November listening to a live feed of the genocide trial for Nuon Chea, a former Khmer Rouge leader. Mr. Nuon Chea’s Dutch defense lawyer let his bar membership lapse.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: An international tribunal dismissed a Dutch lawyer who had defended one of Khmer Rouge leaders. The lawyer’s bar membership lapsed in 2016.
item.dc:creator: JULIA WALLACE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: A Bright Green ‘Christmas Comet’ Will Fly the Closest to Earth in Centuries
item.media:description: The comet 46P/Wirtanen as seen from France through a telescope this month.
item.media:credit: Nicolas Biver/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The comet, called 46P/Wirtanen, will streak near Earth on Sunday and be visible in some places with the naked eye.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA CARON

item.title: NORWAY Dispatch: Where Reindeer Are a Way of Life
item.media:description: A boy jumping into the snow in Kautokeino, where many families are herders.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: The indigenous Sami people have fought for generations to preserve their identity. The latest battles are against Norway’s limits on reindeer herds.
item.dc:creator: NADIA SHIRA COHEN

item.title: The Special Counsel Is Fighting a Witness in Court. Who Is It?
item.media:description: The investigation led by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, is shrouded in mysteries.
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.description: The office of Robert S. Mueller III is in a closed-door legal battle to force a witness to testify. Here’s what we know about the dispute.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: On Pro Football: The Ravens’ Down-to-Earth Approach Is Unnerving the N.F.L.
item.media:description: Quarterback Lamar Jackson is averaging 84 yards per game rushing since taking over as a starter for the Ravens.
item.media:credit: David Eulitt/Getty Images
item.description: In an era when offenses emphasize the pass, Baltimore is doing just the opposite, and its emerging ground game is leaving other teams flummoxed.
item.dc:creator: BILL PENNINGTON

item.title: Maybe It’s Not Taxes That Scare Off Business but Failing Subways
item.media:description: The evening rush at Court Square station in Long Island City, Queens, where Amazon plans to build a new headquarters.
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.description: Amazon is coming to New York despite the city’s transit horrors. Other companies may not be so forgiving.
item.dc:creator: GINIA BELLAFANTE

item.title: Playlist: The Playlist: David Byrne’s Paranoid Party, and 10 More New Songs
item.media:description: David Byrne recorded a live EP in Brooklyn that’s named after a rave review in the British music magazine NME.
item.media:credit: Bryan Derballa for The New York Times
item.description: Hear new tracks by Avril Lavigne, Robin Thicke, American Football and others.
item.dc:creator: JON PARELES, JON CARAMANICA and GIOVANNI RUSSONELLO

item.title: The Fix: Spying on the Dog (or Cat)
item.description: Do you really want to know what your pets are doing while you’re away?
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE HIGGINS

item.title: Editors’ Choice: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
item.description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.

item.title: 5 Cheap(ish) Things for Cold Weather Running
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.description: Brrrrr.
item.dc:creator: JEN A. MILLER

item.title: How to Officiate Your First Wedding (and Why You’d Want To)
item.media:credit: Albert Tercero
item.description: You can help a friend or loved one turn their special day into something remarkable, if you’re willing — but getting ordained is the easy part.
item.dc:creator: WHITSON GORDON

item.title: Vows: She Proposed That He Be Her Caddie. They’ve Worked to Avoid the Rough.
item.media:description: Jean Chua and Wesley Griswold were married Nov. 11 in Asheville, N.C. They both were college golfers and, later, he caddied for her when she played professionally.
item.media:credit: Jacob Biba for The New York Times
item.description: Jean Chua first asked Wesley Griswold to join her on the L.P.G.A. Tour, but he was not a pandering caddie, or boyfriend, and that didn’t always sit well.
item.dc:creator: LINDA MARX

item.title: Sunday Routine: How Marky Ramone, Punk Rocker, Spends His Sundays
item.media:description: At home.
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.description: When he is not compiling music for his SiriusXM show or internet radio channel, Ramone takes in live jazz and watches retro sci-fi movies.
item.dc:creator: TAMMY La GORCE

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: On ‘Counterpart’ and ‘Berlin Station,’ Spies to Keep You Company in the Cold
item.media:description: J.K. Simmons as Howard Silk in “Counterpart.”
item.media:credit: Nicole Wilder-Shattuck/Starz
item.description: Two entertaining espionage thrillers, on Starz and Epix, both take place in Berlin, where secret agents are part of the atmosphere.
item.dc:creator: MIKE HALE

item.title: Five Weeknight Dishes: Fast Recipes for the Craziest Time of Year
item.media:credit: Romulo Yanes for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Vivian Lui.
item.description: It’s the busy season, so give yourself a break with recipes you can knock out in record time.
item.dc:creator: EMILY WEINSTEIN

item.title: Best Movies of 2018
item.media:description: The year’s best movies include, clockwise from top left, “Minding the Gap,” “First Reformed,” “Burning,” “Happy as Lazzaro” and “Private Life.”
item.media:credit: Clockwise from bottom left: Jojo Whilden/Netflix; Hulu; A24; Well Go Usa; Netflix
item.description: Our chief film critics choose the films that moved them this year.
item.dc:creator: MANOHLA DARGIS and A.O. SCOTT
item.category: Hale County This Morning, This Evening (Movie)

item.title: N.F.L. Injury Analysis as Fast as You Can Say Ouch
item.media:description: Dr. David Chao has plenty of screens going on the typical N.F.L. Sunday at his home in La Jolla, Calif.
item.media:credit: Sandy Huffaker for The New York Times
item.description: David Chao, a former team doctor for the Chargers, has become a popular in-game analyst on Twitter from his couch. But is it responsible for him and others to diagnose from a distance?
item.dc:creator: ZACH SCHONBRUN

item.title: A Salamander of Legend Emerges From Southern Swamps
item.media:description: The newest named salamander in the animal kingdom: the reticulated siren.
item.media:credit: David Steen
item.description: The reticulated siren is the largest vertebrate discovered in the United States in decades.
item.dc:creator: ASHER ELBEIN

item.title: Ask Well: Is Eating Deli Meats Really That Bad for You?
item.media:credit: Devin Yalkin for The New York Times
item.description: Even small amounts of processed meat increase the risk of colorectal cancer.
item.dc:creator: RONI CARYN RABIN

item.title: Voices: Am I ‘Old’?
item.description: As with beauty, the meaning of “old” depends on the person you ask.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN PETROW
